reviewText: From Cameron Crowe's notebook...Notes for "Elizabethtown II: The Music of Life"1. Must make the relationship between Drew (Orland Bloom) and Claire (Kirsten Dunst) more believable. Drew Baylor (Orlando Bloom), a wunderkind at an athletic shoe company in Portland, who gets fired because his newest design will cost the company close to $1 billion dollars, meets Claire (Kirsten Dunst), the irrepressible flight attendant during his flight to Elizabethtown, Kentucky, for his father's funeral. In the first film, they meet during the flight and she practically forces herself upon him. In most romantic comedies, there is a "meet cute" scene, where the two people meet in an unexpected, funny way. I wasn't able to come up with that, so I had Claire force herself into Drew's life. The only way this would work even remotely would be for Drew to be a mess. Which is why he fails at his job, in his relationship and he has a strained relationship with his dad, which isn't helped by the fact that he died, so he is a mess. This is the only way anyone would be even remotely attracted to someone as annoying as Claire.In the next film, what will their relationship be? The first film has them getting together (?) and forming a bond. This is why I included a lot of shots of Claire staring at Drew and smiling in a forlorn way. I think it works.Maybe they should be fighting in the beginning of the film and the film is about their journey back together? Yeah, that could work.NOTE: Concerned that all of the characters are defined by buzzwords: suicidal, irrepressible, wunderkind. For sequel, should try to establish more layers for all characters. I used to be able to do this. Watch "Almost Famous" and "Jerry Maguire" again for inspiration. Don't know what happened.The journey back together could be an excuse for another of Claire's crazy maps. (Check into merchandising possibilities!!!!!) In the first film, as Drew prepares to take his father's ashes back to California, Claire gives him a huge, handmade map including instructions about where to stop, for how long, what to eat, what to appreciate. All set to music she (I!) picked. Talk about your control freaks. She made a couple of dozen CDs to accompany the trip. Great excuse for me to include just about every song I have every enjoyed, in my entire life. The loud, constant music also allows me to cover up any obnoxious dialogue that may not be working.2. Because I have used up all of my favorite songs, there will be fewer to choose from for the sequel, so less music. Which means they will have to talk more. Hmm? Not sure about that.3. Don't understand why the studio wouldn't let me call the film "Elizabethtown: The Music of Death". Funny reference to the sheer number of songs on the soundtrack. Great excuse to release multiple soundtracks and make a lot of ancillary revenue. Paramount is so gonna love this. There is so much music on the soundtrack that it will be difficult for many people to sit through, but as the filmmaker, I have to go with my vision.4. Orlando Bloom is a handsome guy, but perhaps I made him too uninteresting. In the sequel, he could go on a journey of extreme sports; hang gliding, zip lining, etc. That would help breathe some life into his character. It would also give them a destination for the road trip.I had too many shots of Bloom doing crazy things with no dialogue. He stops in the middle of the road, dancing on one leg, pumping his fist in the air, because Claire recommended he do this. I think it works, even though Bloom seems a bit manipulated throughout by Claire and the CDs. It was the absolute right decision to have about twenty minutes of the road trip with no dialogue from Bloom, narrated by Kirsten Dunst. Neither is a great actor, but having Dunst narrate Bloom's journey at least makes it interesting. Right?I also think it was absolutely the right decision to have the road trip at the end of the film. The slowest part at the end. Brilliant!!!!In the next film, if they are traveling together, how will I solve this problem?5. Kirsten Dunst is a good actress, but she may have been a little over the top on the first film. Make sure she plays it down in "II". From the moment she first appears on screen, she seems inquisitive, at times, she seems crazy. She practically forces herself upon Bloom's Drew. Not sure it worked. Also, the entire film is about their relationship, yet the relationship remains tentative at best, until the very end. It was a bit maddening really, but that's what the audience wants right? I'm sure the 18- 34 demographic that the film is made for will appreciate it. It's a bit like the relationship between Rachel and Ross on "Friends". Yay!6. I really like the scenes of Drew interacting with his extended family in Elizabethtown. This seems to be the section of the film that works the best, is the most genuine. How can I get them back to Elizabethtown in the sequel? Or do the country relatives come out to "California" and see Drew and his family in Portland, Oregon?The relationship between Drew's cousin Jessie (Paul Schneider), his young son, and his father, Uncle Dale (Loudon Wainright) works really well. We really get a feel for the dynamic of their relationship and how they interact with one another. Paul Deen (from TV's Food Network) appears as Aunt Dora and she does a good job. She is a bit more precocious, but not in an obnoxious way. The southern relatives are, overall, very level and no imbued with the typical stereotypes you would expect. Except for the whole "California" thing. Groan. What was I thinking.7. Unfortunately, these are counteracted by the scenes involving Susan Sarandon and Judy Greer as Drew's mom and sister. I guess I went too over the top with these. I thought it would be funny to have Hollie (Sarandon) try to learn how to repair cars, tap dance, etc., as her method of dealing with the grief of losing her husband. I thought she could pull it off. Normally, she is such a great actress. I don't know what happened. But it is definitely all her fault.The scene where Hollie does a little tap dance tribute to her husband? Brilliant!!!8. Thankfully, the film will make money. Orlando Bloom and Kirsten Dunst are like honey to a bee. Bee = 18 - 34 demographic that will flock to the theaters. Sequel will be justified and I can make the film better, correcting all of the problems in the first film.9. Yay!

reviewText: I became interested in this movie throughMy Year of Flops: The A.V. Club Presents One Man's Journey Deep into the Heart of Cinematic Failurewhere Rabin reviewed this movie twice. The first time, he reviewed as the setting for the series on the AV Club, especially the way of judging the movies based on Bloom's speech about how a fiasco is different than a failure because it tries big and loses big. I was rather taken by the fact that after he wrote the MYOF column and when he was writing the book he went back and reviewed the movie again. The first time he reviewed it, he was hung up on the fact that Kristen Dunst is the Manic Magic Pixie Dream Girl and that she's really annoying. The second time, he focused on the main strength of all Cameron Crowe movies and a strength that still comes through in this one; namely the fact that Crowe characters are kinder to each other and sweeter to the world than most people. His main line from the second review was "I want to live in Cameron Crowe's world."And that makes this movie rather enjoyable. In fact, it makes pretty much every Crowe movie enjoyable. His characters are nice people. There's the occassional jerk like John Mahoney inSay Anythingand Jay Mohr fromJerry Maguirebut for the most part, the characters inhabit a world where people want to understand each other and they really have each other's best intersts at heart.Orlando Bloom stars as a shoe designer who has created the Edsel of footwear. Alec Baldwin shows up as his boss, a man who is sorry to fire him but also cannot ignore that he just lost the company almost a billion dollars. Just as he's about to kill himself, he gets a call from home saying that his father has died. From there on out, he has to negotiate with his father's family for the body with Susan Sarandon as his mother who never felt accepted by that side of the family. By the end of the movie she's made her peace with the family and she's giving stand up comic routines that double as eulogies for everyone. All tensions vanish in a wave of decency.And then there's Kirsten Dunst. I can't love her because she is a MMPDG and that type is usually bunny boiling irritating. And she is just a little too much of a fantasy for the movie. But eventually she kind of wins me over because it's really hard for that kind not to win you over because that fantasy of a lover who totally wants you and will follow you around and try to make your life better whether you want it or not - it's hard to resist. Sure, if she was more realistic she'd be overdosing on pills and dealing with bulimia and cheating with the next guy like Cassie inSkins, Vol. 1but that would really throw off the movie.So, forget about the bad reviews. If you like other Cameron Crowe movies check this one out. ANd even check out with low expectations and you'll be pleasantly surprised by how much you like it.
summary: If you can get over your initial cynicism, it's rather a sweet movie

reviewText: There's a far superior film about a young man who travels to be at his father's funeral - Garden State. Where that film was rich in subtlties and heart and featured a superbly understated performance by Zach Braff, Elizabethtown forces profound emotions but failed to connect with me emotionaly.Orlando Bloom doesn't have the depth to carry off the character of Drew, a designer at a Nike-esque global corporation held unrealistically responsible for costing the company $1 billion in losses due to a poorly received new sneaker. The CEO was played by a pudgy Alec Baldwin. So far, he's proven himself to be strictly supporting-actor talent and nothing Oscar-worthy. Kirsten Dunst is pixie cute as the bubbly flight attendent who does everything possible that would label a man a stalker, but coming from a woman, we're supposed to buy her character's lavishing of attention on Drew as being flirtatious and romantic. There are women out there who are insanely dynamic and very quickly trusting of complete strangers, but they are so rare that Claire, Dunst's character, sets the tone early on that this film will tell its story without feeling obligated to do so with credibility. And that is its biggest downfall.Shortly after hearing of her husband's death, Hollie (Susan Sarandon)reacts by taking up organic cooking, car repair and tap dancing, all at once. Sure. But wait until Claire shows up at the memorial service and references her neighbor consolling her while his member sprouts, and tap dancing to her deceased husband's favorite song. Happens all the time, right? There are so many unbelievable moments like these that they smother any real warmth that was supposed to emerge.The supporting cast is fine, however. Dunst has genuine charisma. The Kentucky family appeared to be accurately portrayed. Crowe's final chapter with Drew driving home and stopping off along the way, is a loving tribute to heartland America in a travelogue, but the idea behind it the road trip, following a "map" put together by Claire is very cheesy and far-fetched. Again.In flashbacks, the young Drew Baylor is played by a couple of actors including one who looked at lot like the character William Miller, the 15 year-old writer featured in Crowe's 2000 hit, Almost Famous.There were no moments when I felt the emotions at anything but a superficial level. This film felt overly long and I couldn't wait for it to be over. I cannot recommend it.
summary: An abject failure from acclaimed director Cameron Crowe.

reviewText: One sad thing is that 'Elizabethtown' is directed by Cameron Crowe, whose 'Almost Famous' is still one of the best films ever made about bitter-sweet memories of youth.  It also has Kate Hudson's star-making acting as "Penny Lane" and Philip Seymour Hoffman's great talent plus very fresh newcomer Patrick Fugit and of course, Frances McDormand.  So what made him write and direct this rambling and disjointed film?  What part of 'Elizabethtown' did he find so attractive?If you have seen the trailer, you know the thin content of the film, about one American shoe-designer Drew (played by miscast Orlando Bloom) who lost the company's millions of dollars, lost his job, and even his love (Jessica Biel).  When he decides to kill himself (in a very strange way), he knows he also lost his daddy.  In the weak opening, you can see the hand of editor, who anyway tries to make things look coherent.Despite the film's clever one-liners and quirky humor, things just don't get better.  While going to his father's funeral in Lousville, Drew meets a gabby flight attendant Claire (Kirsten Dunst).  Here's a story about a new romance, I know, and here's the death of his father, Ok, it's a contrast, and ... Cameron Crowe just cannot stop there, adding a motif after another, all of which add up to nothing.Yes, I know.  'Elizabethtown' is about life, and its bits are beautifully shot, which sometimes comes with insightful observation of life, but Cameron Crowe cannot hold these bits together.  Big commercial failure might be a great shock to an ordinary American guy, but his father's death and broken promise with him is much more shocking to him.  Into 'Elizabethtown' Crowe throws both of them when one is sufficient.  (And why shoe designer in the first place?)But to me, more irritating thing is the actors and acting.  Who did the biggest mistake?  Susan Sarandon who plays Drew's mother who starts to learn tap dance and gives one of the most embarrassing speech at her husband's funeral?  Kirsten Dunst whose acting is far less credible than MJ in 'Spider-man'?  Or Orlando Bloom whose bland acting fails to convince us of the grief of the death of his father?  Sorry if I sound a bit sarcastic, but recent Cameron Crowe films have got too mainstream while 'Almost Famous,' his best so far, was greatly supported by two newcomers.Surely the soundtrack is a great collection of pop music, but besides that there's nothing I can recommend about 'Elizabethtown.'  I would rather leave and go back to 'Almost Famous' and Penny Lane.
summary: Not a Fiasco, But Still a Failure: Rambling and Disjointed

reviewText: Elizabethtown is a movie that will grow on you. Full of some amazing songs, a few great performances and a showcasing of the charms (but little of the shortcomings of "flyover America"), this movie manages to intrigue while it disappoints.And I'm not just saying that 'cause I have a hard time getting past the Orlando Bloom factor.Perhaps its problem is that it is actually three stories (that don't necessarily congeal) in one movie. It begins with the pop psycholgy of the lead character, Bloom as Drew Baylor, exponding upon the corporate rat race (think of Ferris Bueller growing up to work for Apple and you would get the right "tone" of the narration). This section is quickly aborted  ... thankfully, since Bloom seems unable to invoke the dark, burning desperation that would fuel his actions in this "first act" of the film. (Can one be comatized by ennui and still create a Rube Goldberg suicide machine? I didn't buy it.)The second act of the film is where the movie finally takes off. Perhaps it is the introduciton of the Kirsten Dunst character. Slightly underwritten, Claire breathes life into the Bloom (who seems intent on assuming a glum Buster Keaton deadpan through much of the movie), but also into the movie itself. She is radiantly beautiful. (There are times in the movie when the camera simply rest upon her as she stands and she's able to take the breath away of the men in the audience.) At times her character is over-the-top, but her acting never is. Subtlety seems to have been her secret. Her eyes do most of the best acting in the movie - and (big sigh of relief) her Southern accent is never cloying.The examination of the shock of sudden death, mourning and the gathering of family seems more personal, more real. I may be the only man in America that is baffled by the hoopla over "Say Anything" (although it did feature Ione Skye who was ravishing in the recent "Fever Pitch"), but here Cameron Crowe gets it right. He has written some scenes that actually seem like real life. I recognized the rush of activity and self-diversions (the anything-but-mourning ploys) that follow the sudden death of a person that is key to your happiness ... and sometimes your identity.Finally, after an uneven (not sure about Susan Sarrandon tap-dancing), but hilarious - and rocking - memorial tribute (I will now remember Freebird in a completely differet way), the flim gives way to a road trip movie of all things. It was a nice trip down Route 66, but seriously - wouldnt that time been better spent explaining Claire's attraction to Drew (aside from the fact that he is nearly as pretty as she is)?In the end, the merits of this movie rest in the casting. The first act features Alec Baldwin doing a more zen-friendly, Oregon granola take on his Glengarry Glenn Ross character and the deliciously icy Jessica Biel.Both Susan Sarandon (whose talents are wasted here, but sorely needed) and Judy Greer (who I just figured out played one of my favorite characters in "The Village") bring an energy to their scenes that make one wonder if Bloom's character wasn't adopted.The "Kentucky" company of players includes the pitch-perfect performances by Loudon Wainwright III and Paul Schneider, plus fine performances by Bruce McGill and the Food Network's Paula Deen (who is basically playing her charming self.)I recommend this movie - but give it a chance to grow on you. It's charms are worth a second viewing.
